bibl.title: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to John J. Moran, October 7, 1940

div1.p: [Hench] writes that he doubts Moran has really found the infected-clothing building. [Hench] wants to buy the property.

div1.head: Letter from [Philip Showalter Hench] to John J. Moran, October 7, 1940
div1.opener:
October 7, 1940
Mr. John J. Moran
Avenida Menoccal 455
Havana, Cuba
My dear Mr. Moran:
div1.p:
I was of course delighted with your airmail letter of October 3, and not
a little amused. You were so sure that I would be angry with you. I can assure you that
no one could ever get angry with you and the enormous help that you have given me is such
that I am forever indebted to you. Before I forget it, I am afraid you will be running low
on cash for the various odds and ends that I have asked you to do. I therefore enclose a
check for twenty-five dollars and whether you will wish to pay a photographer or use this
for some other purpose, I leave entirely up to you. Undoubtedly, you have had a number
of taxi-cab charges, running back and forth to the camp, etc. and I must insist upon your
letting me pay for these. I will be expecting other bills from you or from Mrs. Phillips.
I am delighted to know that you are coming to Washington and am anxious to know the date
you will be in Charlottesville.

After receiving your first letter, I waited excitedly for the second but for
reasons which you have explained, it did not arrive until last night. You can imagine how
delighted I am that Miss Rojas and you have uncovered her father's book showing without
doubt that Camp Lazear was on their farm. I am extremely anxious to see the translation
and hope you will have Mrs. Phillips hurry it along to me by airmail. It may take a dollar
or so in postage, but it is worth it to me. (Incidentally, in your postage could you send
me some of the eight-cent Agramonte stamps, and I should like a couple of them uncancelled.
Obviously, this is not Dr. Agramonte. Was it his father?) When I receive your translation
of Dr. Rojas' book, I may ask you to either have one or two pages photographed or, better
yet, I may write Senora Rojas and ask her whether she would be willing to let you bring the
book with you. I think it would be most interesting to our audience to show it to them
and I should like to have it to photostat the pertinent pages. No matter how impressive or
truthful a stenographic translation may be, for purposes of future proof, the most impressive
would be actual photographs of the pertinent pages. I could have this done at the Clinic
at practically no cost to me. It would doubtless be pretty expensive to have the photo-
grapher do it in Havana unless there were only three or four pages to be photographed.

I was much excited by your statements regarding the possible discovery of the
infected clothing building, but there are parts of your letter which make me rather dubious.
Remember that the infected clothing building faced due south. It is described rather
accurately by Reed, who mentions the windows, the entrance, the size, and the “tongued and
grooved boards”, but he does not mention a concrete floor in either of the buildings, and
the army pictures of both these buildings (see especially 17b and c) indicate that the
infected clothing building at least was a few inches off the ground. There are apparently
three steps leading up to it, as shown in photograph 16a. Are you absolutely sure that the
building you are trying to identify as building no. 1 faces due south? As I visualize it on
my map of the Rojas farm, it does not quite face south.

The tongued and grooved boards which you found, sound most interesting. Do
you think that is sufficiently unique in a Cuban house to be considered satisfactory proof?
Assuming you have a copy of your last letter to me of October 5, please note that in one
sentence you say the mosquito building was torn down about four or five years ago. Slabs
of the concrete floor can still be seen in the tilled field where you had some photographs
of me taken, the site being much more to the left, viewed from the front of building no. 1,
than where I stand in the picture. My comments on these sentences are as follows: The way
you write it, you infer that the mosquito building had a concrete floor. I doubt this.
Why would the mosquito building have three steps leading up to it if it had a concrete floor?
Furthermore, how could the concrete floor concern the mosquito building if you found it
“much more to the left from the front of building no. 1”? You will note in photographs
17b and c, and 16a that the two buildings were opposite each other. You also mention Mr.
Z.'s attempts to identify the present tree so closely to what he would have you believe to
be building no. 1. But again note in the photograph already mentioned, that there is no
tree near building no. 1. Either, therefore, the present trees are all younger than forty
years, or the building is not building no. 1. There are no trees in the immediate vicinity
of building no. 2, although there is one some yards away.

You remember Mr. Z's comments to us while I was there. Some of his information
may be correct, but I suspect that most of it is not. You may be able to weed out the false
from the true and still find that the building is no. 1. Next time you go out, could you
take a measuring tape and measure it? Remember that it was exactly 20 x 14 feet. If this
really were building no. 1 and if you will take photograph 16a, b or c, and stand in the
appropriate place, should not the Rojas farmhouse be visible in these photographs? In the
background on the left? Regardless of whether you are right or wrong, I shall be delighted
to have whatever photographs you have had taken. I should much prefer to buy extra photo-
graphs to get the right one than to buy too few. I hope they are all on the way. My first
inclination last night was to wire you to have Pogolotti act as my agent and get a price
for this shack and a small plot of land around it. Certainly the shack should be worth very
little to anyone else. My purpose in doing this was to buy it promptly, so that it would be
cared for until I can try to collect from interested parties enough to restore it and preserve
it. If you are willing, I would still like you to ask Pogolotti how much he thinks it would
cost, but I hope that Mr. Z., if he is the owner, will not jack up the price way out of reach
because of our interest in it. What would be the cost for an option on this building until
I could get down, perhaps in February? Should I buy it I would not ask the owner to leave
(or tenant) but merely ask Mr. Pogolotti to see to it that it could be inspected every few
weeks so that no harm would come to it. Don't misunderstand me. I would not expect the
Cuban government to contribute a nickel, but if that really is building no. 1, I am sure
I could raise enough money to tear down the junky additions and to restore the building
as necessary. At the moment, I am only interested in buying enough land around it to protect
the building. The above was my inclination as of last night. But having studied the pictures
and documents again several hours, and not being too sure that Mr. Z has given you correct
information, this morning I am cautious and would merely ask you and Pogolotti to make a
quiet and tentative appraisal of the real estate value and of an option and final charge.

I would give my eye teeth to own Dr. Rojas' day book, but doubtless the family
may want to keep it in their possession for awhile. It should eventually go in a museum and I
would like to tell them this some time. If they would be willing to leave it to the Museum of
the Mayo Clinic, I could assure them it would be properly taken care of for all time. Other
suitable institutions would be the Army Medical Museum or Johns Hopkins, the Walter Reed
Hospital, or University of Virginia. Naturally, I wish the Mayo Clinic may eventually win out,
and to replace it I can assure you I would have the entire thing photostated so that they might
have permanent record as long as they wish it. I shall of course await further letters from
you with great interest.
